title: Clinton Sundberg
text:
Clinton Charles Sundberg (December 7, 1903 (some sources say 1906) – December 14, 1987) was an American character actor in film and stage.
Early years.
Sundberg was born in <a href="Appleton%2C%20Minnesota">Appleton, Minnesota</a>. He graduated from <a href="Hamline%20University">Hamline University</a> in <a href="St.%20Paul%2C%20Minnesota">St. Paul, Minnesota</a>, where he was active in drama, president of his fraternity, and captain of the tennis team.
Career.
Sundberg left teaching English literature for acting, appearing in plays in <a href="Repertory%20theatre">stock theater</a> in New England. He appeared in a number of <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> plays, debuting in "Nine Pine Street" (1933). His most notable roles were Mr. Kraler in the original 1957 production of "<a href="The%20Diary%20of%20Anne%20Frank">The Diary of Anne Frank</a>" and Mortimer Brewster (as a replacement) in the 1944 "<a href="Arsenic%20and%20Old%20Lace%20%28play%29">Arsenic and Old Lace</a>".
He became a contract player at <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a> where he appeared in numerous supporting roles in films of the late 1940s and early 1950s. He played Mike, the bartender who listens to <a href="Judy%20Garland">Judy Garland</a>'s character's troubles in "<a href="Easter%20Parade%20%28film%29">Easter Parade</a>". In the 1949 film "<a href="In%20the%20Good%20Old%20Summertime">In the Good Old Summertime</a>," which also starred Garland and <a href="Van%20Johnson">Van Johnson</a>, he played a friendly co-worker and confidante of Johnson's character. He also played the hotel owner who hired <a href="Annie%20Oakley">Annie Oakley</a> to enter the shooting contest against <a href="Frank%20E.%20Butler">Frank Butler</a> in "<a href="Annie%20Get%20Your%20Gun%20%28musical%29">Annie Get Your Gun</a>". He later made several television appearances, including two episodes of "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>": "The Case of the Drowsy Mosquito" in 1963 and "The Case of the Scarlet Scandal" in 1966. He also appeared in several television commercials.
In 1957, Sundberg appeared in a TV episode of <a href="Have%20Gun%20-%20Will%20Travel">Have Gun - Will Travel</a>, "The Englishman".
In 1962, Sundberg was cast in the lead guest-starring role of Luther Boardman, a naive but troublesome newspaper publisher who comes to <a href="Laramie%2C%20Wyoming">Laramie</a>, <a href="Wyoming">Wyoming</a>, to capture the story of "real West" gunfighters in "The Man Behind the News", one of the last episodes of the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>/<a href="Warner%20Brothers">Warner Brothers</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series, "<a href="Lawman%20%28TV%20series%29">Lawman</a>", which starred <a href="John%20Russell%20%28actor%29">John Russell</a> as Marshal Dan Troop. <a href="Hal%20Baylor">Hal Baylor</a> appears in the episode as gunfighter Mort Peters, whom Boardman (Sundberg) goads into a shootout with Troop.
